repnme.cdata!:
Guinea - Second, Third, and Fourth
            Structural Adjustment; Public Enterprise Sector
            Rationalization & Privatization Technical Assistance;
            and Financial Sector Adjustment Credit Projects

abstracts.cdata!:
The five projects examined for Guinea,
            the Second, Third, And Fourth Structural Adjustment, Public
            Enterprise Sector Rationalization & Privatization
            Technical Assistance, and Financial Sector Adjustment
            Credits have outcomes ranging from moderately unsatisfactory
            to unsatisfactory.  In all projects the sustainability is
            unlikely and Bank and Borrower's performances are
            considered highly unsatisfactory with modest or negligible
            institutional development. The main lessons derived from
            these operations for the Bank are: adjustment lending
            operations should be underpinned by a high quality and
            adequate economic and sector work program; time-bound,
            monitorable indicators should be used to verify performance;
            both revenue and expenditure issues should be addressed in
            reducing fiscal deficits; single tranche credits should be
            used only when the government has an established track
            record of good policy performance; IDA staff re-assignments
            should not be disruptive to IDA operations and client
            relations; timely warning should be given to management and
            the Board of rising IDA risk exposure from an unsustainable
            debt burden; and donor lending can create incentives to
            mismanage the economy

repnme.cdata!:
Guinea - Public Enterprise Sector
            Rationalization and Privatization Technical Assistance
            Project (PATSEP)

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Public Enterprise
            Sector Rationalization and Privatization Technical
            Assistance Project (PATSEP) for Guinea was unsatisfactory.
            The project failed to achieve its major objectives,
            institutional development was negligible, sustainability is
            unlikely, and the performance of both the Bank and Borrower
            was unsatisfactory. Two important lessons can be learned
            from this project. First, the Bank should carefully assess
            the Government's commitment to the operation. If it is
            found to be lacking, the Bank should take the time and
            provide the resources to help strengthen the commitment,
            even if it means delaying the operation. Second, the Bank
            should improve its supervision capacity and strictly apply
            the standardized performance criteria. Procedures should be
            in place to ensure consistency of project supervision from
            one task manager to another and a smooth transition between
            task managers before reassignment.

18156043.theme: State-owned enterprise restructuring and privatization,Law reform,Administrative and civil service reform
18156043.majtheme: Financial and private sector development,Rule of law,Public sector governance

repnme.cdata!:
Guinea - Public Enterprise Sector
            Rationalization and Privatization Technical Assistance Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Public Enterprise Sector
            Rationalization and Privatization Technical Assistance
            Project (PATSEP) will consist of two components: (a) support
            to the second divestiture program; and (b) support to the
            Government's public enterprise (PE) sector management.
            Activities under the first component will be designed to
            help the Government formulate and implement the second
            divestiture program covering some 46 PEs.  They include: 1)
            the services of a privatization expert; 2) consulting
            services for the privatization or liquidation of specific
            PEs; 3) advisory services on the legal reform program with a
            view to fostering private sector development; and (4) the
            services of two experts, one internationally and one
            nationally recruited, to help the Government and the
            targeted PEs develop the reorientation programs for
            redundant PE employees. The second component aims at
            reinforcing the Government's capacity to manage a
            streamlined PE sector, in particular, to apply more rigorous
            financial control and discipline.  Activities under this
            component include the services of: 1) a PE reform expert; 2)
            a legal advisor to assist with legal reform; 3) a financial
            expert to restore financial discipline in the sector; 4) a
            management information expert to help with the development
            of a management information system; 5) an expert to help
            develop a regulatory framework to the public utilities; 6)
            studies of additional reform measures; 7) Government agency
            staff training; and 8) logistic support.
